awd_titl_txt: VENTURES-Vision for Excellence at Navajo Technical University in Research and Education in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
Navajo Technical University (NTU) is one of the premier institutions of higher education in the Navajo Nation, providing a unique balance among science, engineering, technology, tradition, and identity rooted in the Dine Philosophy of Education: Nitsahakees, Nahata, Iina, and Siihasin. The proposed project, Vision for Excellence at NTU in Research and Education in STEM (VENTURES), will develop a partnership between NTU and the NSF Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) at Harvard University. By providing research and educational opportunities in materials science that address environmental and health concerns of the Navajo Nation, the partnership will build robust pathways for under-represented Native American students (Navajo) in STEM, from K-12 to undergraduate, and from undergraduate to graduate programs. The goals of this partnership are to: 1) increase the number of Native Americans earning undergraduate degrees in STEM fields, 2) increase the research infrastructure at NTU so that students and faculty can perform research within their own community, 3) increase the number of Native Americans entering and completing graduate programs in materials science and related fields, and 4) include Native American perspectives and methods of inquiry in materials science research. Additionally, the research program will allow for ample opportunities for students and faculty to communicate back to and receive feedback from the Navajo community via work with K-12 schools, and the Navajo Chapter Houses. Technology transfer from Harvard to NTU will facilitate growth at NTU in research  activities in materials science and engineering; concomitantly, the collaboration will draw upon Navajo traditional knowledge and ways of learning in defining and implementing the research and educational activities. Research and educational results with joint authorship from the partnership will also be disseminated in peer-reviewed journals and conferences. 


The two materials research areas in this award are relevant to health and environmental issues that are of immediate importance to the Navajo Nation. Research area 1, which will focus on materials and techniques for detection of low concentrations of pollutants, is motivated by the long history of uranium mining on the Navajo Nation, as well as more recent extraction activities, such as fracking. Research area 2, which will study mechanical properties of cell membranes, will help to address a growing health concern for the Navajo people - a rising incidence of high cholesterol and associated coronary disease. Professor Thiagarajan Soundappan (Navajo Technical University), and Professor David Weitz (Harvard University) will lead collaborative teams of 8-10 faculty from NTU and Harvard. Collaborative research teams in research area 1 will develop and test electrodes for detection of mining contaminants, and develop microfluidics-based laboratory models for flow and detection of contaminants through soil. Research area 2 will investigate the ability of phytosterols to act as cholesterol surrogates and how they modify the sterol profile of mammalian cell membranes, as well as examine the resulting membrane biophysical properties (using capillary microfluidic techniques). By linking each research area to an issue of concern to the Navajo people, this team will be able to achieve the objectives of increasing enrollment in STEM fields at NTU, and will inspire students to continue to graduate research in materials and related fields. In addition, the highly accessible research techniques can be readily adapted into courses at NTU and outreach activities to the Navajo Nation, incorporating cultural knowledge and practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report

 The primary goals of the NSF PREM Seed Project at Navajo Technical University (NTU), entitled Vision for Excellence at Navajo Technical University in Research and Education in STEM: to partner with the Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) at Harvard to create collaborative, cutting-edge, and culturally informed research opportunities in materials science and other STEM fields at NTU and at Harvard, and to develop pathways for students to pursue STEM careers and advanced study.

 The key outcomes of the NTU PREM Seed project include:

  1. Establishing new research facilities in materials science at NTU in partnership with the Harvard MRSEC, including a microfluidics laboratory, a testbed for electrochemical sensors, and a soft robotics laboratory, so that students can participate in year-round research that is culturally and economically relevant for the Navajo Nation.
  2. Increasing the number of Native Americans earning undergraduate degrees in STEM by supporting students in new and expanded 4-year STEM degree programs at NTU.
  3. Increasing the number of Native Americans entering graduate programs in materials science and related fields by creating robust pathways for NTU students through undergraduate training and post-baccalaureate programs.
  4. Incorporating Native American perspectives, traditional knowledge, and inquiry methods in materials science research, STEM courses and outreach activities.

 Intellectual merit: The NSF PREM Seed project enabled NTU to establish new research facilities, including the microfluidics laboratory, an electrochemical sensor testbed, and a soft robotics laboratory by transferring science and technology from Harvard to NTU. Using these facilities, NTU undergraduate students have used droplet-based microfluidics to encapsulate therapeutic agents and study their controlled release. In addition, the NTU students created and characterized paper-based and ion-selective electrodes for electrochemical applications at NTU. Students also received training in soft robotics, from initial design to their soft lithographic fabrication. These projects focused on Navajo cultural, economic and health applications, including: encapsulation of traditional medicines using microfluidics; using low-cost paper electrochemical sensors for detection of heavy metals from abandoned mines; and developing soft actuators for use in agriculture and veterinary care. Many NTU students presented their PREM research projects at national conferences. The establishment of crucial research infrastructure at NTU ensures that undergraduate students can continue to carry out research relevant to their community within their community, thereby attracting more Native Americans to STEM fields. The PREM Seed engaged 16 funded students and 5 affiliates in PREM research over the course of the grant.

 Broader impacts: The NSF PREM Seed project also enhanced the educational activities at NTU. In partnership with the Harvard MRSEC, NTU organized and hosted educational and technical workshops, including the science of cooking Native foods, poster presentation training, on-campus outreach events, and school visits.  These initiatives helped inspire the next generation of students from the Navajo community. The NTU student club, BiCEPS (Biology, Chemistry, Engineering, and Physical Science), led several outreach activities, including visits to local K-12 schools to present PREM research-related activities. In addition, local K-12 teachers participated in virtual professional development programs, which focused on creating practical learning experiences in their classrooms to spur Native American students’ interest in STEM.

 Importantly, the NSF PREM Seed provided NTU undergraduate students an opportunity to participate in the Research Experiences for Undergraduates program at Harvard University.  Over the course of this PREM Seed, 10 NTU students spent 10 weeks at Harvard to carry out the research (microfluidics, electrochemistry and soft matter). Some NTU students had never traveled out of the state before. NTU faculty traveled to Harvard each summer to engage with their students and the MRSEC community. The MRSEC team also visited the NTU campus, conducted multiple research trainings and professional development workshops for NTU students, and visited local school districts to recruit students for NTU. During the pandemic, a PREM Seed supplement was instrumental in maintaining community among the NTU students through virtual programs with the Harvard MRSEC, including professional development and hands-on adaptation of MRSEC-developed science and cooking activities to focus on traditional Navajo foods in their home kitchens.

 The PREM has developed pathways for NTU students into STEM careers and advanced study through intensive undergraduate training and a new post-baccalaureate program at Harvard. To date, 2 students are in the first year of Ph.D. studies (1 at Harvard, 1 at Arizona State University), and 2 students are in a post-baccalaureate bridge-to-Ph.D. program at Harvard.  

 In summary, the NSF PREM Seed project at NTU has established a strong foundation, including new pathways for students, for future research and education in materials science and related STEM fields.

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2023
Modified by: Thiagarajan Soundappan

Project Outcome Report

 The primary goals of the NSF PREM Seed Project at Navajo Technical University (NTU), entitled Vision for Excellence at Navajo Technical University in Research and Education in STEM: to partner with the Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) at Harvard to create collaborative, cutting-edge, and culturally informed research opportunities in materials science and other STEM fields at NTU and at Harvard, and to develop pathways for students to pursue STEM careers and advanced study.

 The key outcomes of the NTU PREM Seed project include:

Establishing new research facilities in materials science at NTU in partnership with the Harvard MRSEC, including a microfluidics laboratory, a testbed for electrochemical sensors, and a soft robotics laboratory, so that students can participate in year-round research that is culturally and economically relevant for the Navajo Nation.
Increasing the number of Native Americans earning undergraduate degrees in STEM by supporting students in new and expanded 4-year STEM degree programs at NTU.
Increasing the number of Native Americans entering graduate programs in materials science and related fields by creating robust pathways for NTU students through undergraduate training and post-baccalaureate programs. 
Incorporating Native American perspectives, traditional knowledge, and inquiry methods in materials science research, STEM courses and outreach activities.


 Intellectual merit: The NSF PREM Seed project enabled NTU to establish new research facilities, including the microfluidics laboratory, an electrochemical sensor testbed, and a soft robotics laboratory by transferring science and technology from Harvard to NTU. Many NTU students presented their PREM research projects at national conferences. The establishment of crucial research infrastructure at NTU ensures that undergraduate students can continue to carry out research relevant to their community within their community, thereby attracting more Native Americans to STEM fields. The PREM Seed engaged 16 funded students and 5 affiliates in PREM research over the course of the grant.

 Broader impacts: The NSF PREM Seed project also enhanced the educational activities at NTU. In partnership with the Harvard MRSEC, NTU organized and hosted educational and technical workshops, including the science of cooking Native foods, poster presentation training, on-campus outreach events, and school visits.  These initiatives helped inspire the next generation of students from the Navajo community. The NTU student club, BiCEPS (Biology, Chemistry, Engineering, and Physical Science), led several outreach activities, including visits to local K-12 schools to present PREM research-related activities. Some NTU students had never traveled out of the state before. NTU faculty traveled to Harvard each summer to engage with their students and the MRSEC community. During the pandemic, a PREM Seed supplement was instrumental in maintaining community among the NTU students through virtual programs with the Harvard MRSEC, including professional development and hands-on adaptation of MRSEC-developed science and cooking activities to focus on traditional Navajo foods in their home kitchens.

 The PREM has developed pathways for NTU students into STEM careers and advanced study through intensive undergraduate training and a new post-baccalaureate program at Harvard. To date, 2 students are in the first year of Ph.D. studies (1 at Harvard, 1 at Arizona State University), and 2 students are in a post-baccalaureate bridge-to-Ph.D. program at Harvard.  

 In summary, the NSF PREM Seed project at NTU has established a strong foundation, including new pathways for students, for future research and education in materials science and related STEM fields.
